title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices to study laws and regulations affecting Federal campaigns, make recommendations for change, and consider various aspects such as campaign financing, candidate qualifications, trust in the political process, media access, and other relevant matters. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes a 9-member Commission from the private sector, with appointments made by various political leaders. The chairperson is selected by majority vote within 7 days, with a provision for discharge if no selection is made within 30 days. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes a 9-member Commission from the private sector, with appointments made by various political leaders. Vacancies in the Commission are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member is entitled to receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A quorum of six members is required for decision-making, and meetings are held at the call of the chairperson or at the request of six members. The chairperson of the Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 can appoint staff without following standard government hiring procedures. They can also procure temporary services as needed. Additionally, fast track procedures are in place for recommendations. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 allows for expedited consideration of recommendations for changes in federal campaign laws. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing their study and any agreed-upon recommendations. If 7 or more members agree on a recommendation, they must prepare a bill to implement it, which will be considered quickly by Congress. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 allows for expedited consideration of recommendations for changes in federal campaign laws. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report under section 6. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act.
